Optimization problem definition

Design Constraints

This script contains the default (standard) design constraints used with the PolyhedralDesignSpace as well as the class affording a designer the ability to create a custom defined constraint.

class mango.optimization_features.design_constraints.CustomDesignConstraint(name: str, design_constraint: Callable | None = None, extra_params: dict | None = None)[source]

Bases: object

This class lets the user define a custom function which can be assigned as an extra design constraint. This is a slight WIP as I may want to convert this to a Python wrapper, but I am not sure about the logistics (or if this is even a good idea).

The function can really be defined as anything, however it should be noted that there are no checks here to see how “good” a constraint is or is not, and that is at the discretion of the user.

Parameters

name : String unique identifies of the constraint name design_constraint : A Python function defining the constraint. For example, if you have a constraint as:

def foo(input_vars, extra_params):

constraint_code

Then you would pass in CustomDesignConstraint(name=’foo’, design_constraint=foo,

extra_params=extra_params)

extra_params : A dictionary of constants / values that a user may want to use in the custom constraint

design_constraint: Callable = None
evaluate_constraint(input_parameters)[source]

This function simply calls the Callable function

extra_params: dict = None
name: str
class mango.optimization_features.design_constraints.PolyhedralDefaultConstraints(extra_constraints: list | None = None, scaffold_routing_algorithm: str = 'DAEDALUS', min_face_angle: float = 20, min_edge_length: int = 39, max_edge_length: int = 250, max_number_basepairs_in_scaffold: int = 7249)[source]

Bases: object

This default constraints class contains methods which can examine a design space and determine if the design is compliant w.r.t.: edge lengths, scaffold required to create the design, etc. If looking to constrain certain aspects of the design, please see the CustomDesignConstraint class.

Parameters

extra_constraints : List of CustomDesignConstraint objects scaffold_routing_algorithm : Which automated algorithm is to be used on the exported PLY file, defualt DAEDALUS min_face_angle : Floating point minimal allowable face angle (in degrees). Too low of a value can cause issues

in the exported design.

min_edge_length : Integer min number of nucleotides any one edge can have; default is 39 due to ATHENA restrictions. max_edge_length : Integer max number of nucleotides any one edge can have max_number_basepairs_in_scaffold : Integer value for max # of nucleotides to allow in a design. Note that here we

estimate the # of nts in the scaffold, and there may be some error in exported designs.

static broken_preserved_edge(design_space: PolyhedralSpace) → tuple[bool, float][source]

This method verifies that any PreservedEdge maintains as an edge during the generative process and is not manipulated via grammar application.

Parameters:

design_space – The current design represented by its design_space to be validated for constraint compliance

Returns:

True if the design is invalid, False if the design is valid. Also returns time of function execution for internal logging / development purposes

call_function_with_params(function: Callable[[...], Tuple[bool, float]], params: Dict[str, Any]) → Tuple[bool, float][source]
check_constraints(design_space: PolyhedralSpace, constraint_set: list, compare_space: PolyhedralSpace | None = None) → tuple[source]

This is the top-level method which calls all constraints in the constraint_set (as well as any custom defined constraints).

Parameters:

  • design_space – The current design represented by its design_space to be validated for constraint compliance

  • constraint_set – List of strings dictating which constraints are being used in the study

  • compare_space – Design space of the prior design_space which is used to validate against the active design

static check_face_intersections(mesh: Trimesh) → tuple[bool, float][source]

This function validates whether the faces of the mesh overlap or not signalling an “invalid” mesh.

Parameters:

mesh – Trimesh mesh of the active design_space which auto-calculates all face angles

Returns:

True if the design is invalid, False if the design is valid. Also returns time of function execution for internal logging / development purposes

create_constraint_dictionary(design_space: PolyhedralSpace) → None[source]

This function creates the necessary dictionary which stores parameters (such as the trimesh) who are used in validating the design constraints of the problem

Parameters:

design_space – The current design represented by its design_space to be validated for constraint compliance

static edge_in_excluded_region(design_space: PolyhedralSpace) → tuple[bool, float][source]

This method determines if an edge crossed through a face in the excluded regions list.

Parameters:

design_space – The current design represented by its design_space to be validated for constraint compliance

Returns:

True if the design is invalid, False if the design is valid. Also returns time of function execution for internal logging / development purposes

extra_constraints: list | None = None
static find_intersecting_edges(design_space: PolyhedralSpace, compare_space: PolyhedralSpace | None = None) → tuple[bool, float][source]

This function instead considers the design as an invalid polyhedra where faces may intersect one another. This specific function will consider edges has cylindrical bounding boxes that may not collide with one another through a collision detection algorithm.

Parameters:

  • design_space – The current design represented by its design_space to be validated for constraint compliance

  • compare_space – Design space of the prior design_space which is used to validate against the active design

Returns:

True if the design is invalid, False if the design is valid. Also returns time of function execution for internal logging / development purposes

invalid_edge_lengths(all_lengths: list) → tuple[bool, float][source]

This method simply verifies that all edge lengths in a design are between the min and max allowable value set by the user.

Parameters:

all_lengths – List of edge length values [15, 20, 25] (nm)

Returns:

True if the design is invalid, False if the design is valid. Also returns time of function execution for internal logging / development purposes

invalid_face_angles(mesh: Trimesh) → tuple[bool, float][source]

This method analyzes a mesh and assesses the faces of the mesh to assure none of the face angles are below the set minimal value.

Parameters:

mesh – Trimesh mesh of the active design_space which auto-calculates all face angles

Returns:

True if the design is invalid, False if the design is valid. Also returns time of function execution for internal logging / development purposes

max_edge_length: int = 250
max_number_basepairs_in_scaffold: int = 7249
min_edge_length: int = 39
min_face_angle: float = 20
static outside_design_space(design_space: PolyhedralSpace, all_edges: array) → tuple[bool, float][source]

This method determines if a design is outside the bounding_box

Parameters:

  • design_space – The current design represented by its design_space to be validated for constraint compliance

  • all_edges – List of all edge node pairs

Returns:

True if the design is invalid, False if the design is valid. Also returns time of function execution for internal logging / development purposes

scaffold_routing_algorithm: str = 'DAEDALUS'
update_params(design_space: PolyhedralSpace) → None[source]

This function will update the proper value inside of self.params such that future design_constraints can be computationally efficiently checked

Parameters:

design_space – The current design represented by its design_space to be validated for constraint compliance

used_too_much_scaffold(all_lengths: list) → tuple[bool, float][source]

This method estimates the total number of nucleotides a scaffold would require to convert the design_space to a DNA origami design file using the specified automated routing algorithm (eg DAEDALUS). This method is simply an approximation and may over or under-shoot a design. Due to the stochastic nature of this algorithm, it would be prohibitively expensive to constantly compute the total number of nucleotides each design would require, whereas this is much more efficient.

Parameters:

all_lengths – List of edge length values [15, 20, 25] (nm)

Returns:

True if the design is invalid, False if the design is valid. Also returns time of function execution for internal logging / development purposes

static vert_in_excluded_region(design_space: PolyhedralSpace, all_verts: array) → tuple[bool, float][source]

This method determines if a vertex is inside of an excluded region which is not permissible.

Parameters:

  • design_space – The current design represented by its design_space to be validated for constraint compliance

  • all_verts – List of all vertices in [X Y Z] as in [[X1 Y1 Z1], [X2 Y2 Z2], … [XN YN ZN]]

Returns:

True if the design is invalid, False if the design is valid. Also returns time of function execution for internal logging / development purposes

Objective Function

This script simply contains the dataclass for creating an ObjectiveFunction to use to guide the search process for a generative study.

class mango.optimization_features.objective_function.ObjectiveFunction(name: str, objective_equation: Callable | None = None, extra_params: dict | None = None, numDecimals: int = 3)[source]

Bases: object

This class lets the user define a custom function which can be assigned as the objective of the generative process. This is a slight WIP as I may want to convert this to a Python wrapper, but I am not sure about the logistics (or if this is even a good idea). This class is very similar to the CustomDesignConstraint class.

The function can really be defined as anything, however it should be noted that there are no checks here to see how “good” a constraint is or is not, and that is at the discretion of the user.

Parameters

name : String unique identifies of the constraint name objective_equation : A Python function defining the objective. For example, if you have a constraint as:

def bar(input_vars, extra_params):

objective_function_code

Then you would pass in ObjectiveFunction(name=’bar’, design_constraint=bar,

extra_params=extra_params)

extra_params : A dictionary of constants / values that a user may want to use in the custom constraint numDecimals : Floating point value to control precision. Allowing too high of precision, depending on the sampling

sampling, can lead to the optimizers getting stuck in local minima around a certain point.

evaluate_function(input_parameters)[source]
extra_params: dict = None
name: str
numDecimals: int = 3
objective_equation: Callable = None
